Award.AwardTitle: IMR-MIP: High Spatial Resolution Sampling Scanning SQUID Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration: This award from the Division of Materials Research supports Stanford University with the conceptual engineering design and development of a prototype scanning sampling Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID) microscope. High spatial resolution sampling scanning SQUID microscopes are among the world?s most sensitive magnetic detectors. The project will provide scientist and engineers with a new imaging capability of time-independent magnetic fields with nanoscale spatial resolution and single electron spin sensitivity. It will enable imaging of time-dependent magnetic fields with 10 picoseconds time resolution. Such measurements of nanomagnetic phenomena are of interest in information technology, biotechnology, and energy technology, as well as fundamental science. The microscope is designed to become a general user tool at two co-located shared user facilities, the Stanford Nanofabrication Facility (SNF), a member of the National Nanofabrication Infrastructure Network, and the Center for Probing the Nanoscale (CPN). The microscope would be a transformative tool in the hands of the users, scientists and engineers, needing to characterize such widely varying materials as superconductors, magnetic nanoparticles, magnetic semiconductors, and multiferroics. The project is based on collaboration between IBM and Stanford. This university-industry collaboration will allow mentoring and hands-on experience for a diverse group of students and postdocs in an industrial environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Superconducting QUantum Interference Devices are super-sensitive detectors of magnetic field. We have designed, built, installed, and now operate a unique scanning SQUID microscope user facility at Stanford University, so that researchers from many fields can image the magnetic fields produced by their devices, materials, and samples. To date we have imaged objects from 25 principlel investigators different sources from 17 institutions in 6 countries. This work has assisted researchers studying materials science (superconductivity,  electronics, and magnetic materials); nanotechnology (carbon nanotubes and nanomagnets), biomedical applications (magnetotactic bacteria, nanomagnetic labels, stem cells, and mammalian cancer cells), and earth sciences (sand samples that impact magnetic-resonance-based geological surveys). These initial studies demonstrate the power of this microscope as a user facility for researchers in diverse areas.

The microscope is designed to be relatively easy to use and to have fast turnaround compared to other scanning SQUID microscopes: up to one sample/day can be run. It features large area (150 micron by 150 micron) piezo scanners, large area (5 mm by 5 mm) coarse positioning, capacitive sensing of the horizontal position, and automated approach of the SQUID sensor to the sample with capacitive touchdown sensing. The sample temperature can be varied from 4.2 degrees above absolute zero to 170 degress above absolute zero, while maintaining the SQUID below its superconducting critical temperature of 9 degrees above absolute zero. As far as we are aware, there is no other user facility for scanning SQUID microscopy in the world.

As a crucial part of the project, we have designed and our collaborators at IBM and HYPRES have fabricated next-generation scanning SQUID sensors. Theoretical simulations show that these next-generation sensors have the potential to set new records for magnetic sensitivity. Although work characterizing our sensors continues, we have already demonstrated micron scale spatial resolution, nanosecond scale sampling of repetitive signals, and few Bohr magneton spin sensitivity with these sensors. The attached image shows a scanning electron microscope image of the pickup loop/field coil region of a scanning SQUID susceptometer with a 1 micron inside diameter pickup loop.
